title: 108_s2981
content: The Act titled "Conventional Arms Threat Reduction Act of 2004" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 includes findings and the sense of Congress. The global proliferation of MANPADS, small arms, and tactical missile systems poses a direct threat to national security. Terrorist and insurgent groups using these weapons hinder peace efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan. The Government Accountability Office estimates 500,000 to 750,000 MANPADS worldwide. Countries possessing these weapons jeopardize international peace and security. The Government Accountability Office estimates 500,000 to 750,000 MANPADS globally. Many countries have these weapons but lack the means to eliminate or secure them. The US lacks a program to address conventional arms threat reduction and missile elimination in other countries. The Department of State has not used the Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund for tactical missile system elimination since 2002. The US Government should provide assistance to countries to secure and eliminate stocks of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems to combat proliferation threats. There should be a consistent emphasis on combating the illicit trade in small arms and light weapons within the broader nonproliferation strategy. The United States aims to help other countries safeguard or eliminate stocks of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems that pose a proliferation threat. This is part of the global program for the safeguarding and elimination of conventional arms. The Secretary of State is authorized to carry out a global program to secure, remove, or eliminate stocks of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems that pose a proliferation threat. This program may include activities such as humanitarian demining, destruction of small arms and light weapons, and assisting countries in safe handling and storage of these weapons. The authorized global program includes assisting countries in safe handling and storage of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems, as well as cooperative programs with international organizations for elimination or safeguarding of these weapons. Actions to manage MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems funded by the United States for security purposes, including security upgrades for storage locations deemed a proliferation threat by the Secretary of State. SEC. 5. OFFICE OF CONVENTIONAL ARMS THREAT REDUCTION. An Office of Conventional Arms Threat Reduction is established within the Department of State to formulate policy and administer programs for conventional arms threat reduction. SEC. 6. REPORT ON CONVENTIONAL ARMS THREAT REDUCTION. The Secretary of State must submit a report on conventional arms threat reduction to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act. The report will detail past State Department efforts, progress in establishing the Office of Conventional Arms Threat Reduction, and country-specific implementation of a global strategy for eliminating or securing conventional weapons. The report required under subsection (a) shall detail the implementation of a global strategy for the elimination or safeguarding of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems, prioritizing efforts based on proliferation sensitivity in each country. It will also evaluate the integration of activities under this Act and other US Government programs to ensure consistency with US policy goals in countries receiving assistance, and describe US programs related to the elimination of tactical missile systems. The report required under subsection (a) will detail the scope and nature of US programs related to the elimination of tactical missile systems in unclassified form, with a possible classified annex. SEC. 7. Authorization of Appropriations: $50,000,000 authorized for the President in fiscal year 2005 for activities under this Act, with a limitation of $10,000,000 until the Secretary of State submits the required report. SEC. 8. Definitions. In this Act, the term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund" refers to a fund established under a specific section of the FREEDOM Support Act. The term "small arms and light weapons" includes various types of firearms and weapons. The curr_chunk describes a variety of weapons including submachine guns, assault rifles, grenade launchers, antiaircraft guns, antitank missiles, mortars, ammunition, hand grenades, landmines, and explosives.
